description.narrative: People, particularly women and other vulnerable groups, have improved access to responsive and accountable justice and human rights protection mechanisms.

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANI

description.narrative:
1.1) Pre-trial detention population (as % of total) 1.2) # of criminal justice sector policies, plans, actions and laws informed by data analysis and public consultation inclusive of women and vulnerable groups
2.1) Legal Aid Act revised and enacted 2.2) Legal aid policy guidelines developed and adopted 2.3) % increase in legal awareness, legal assistance and legal aid services 2.4) # of cases resolved through legal aid in prison and police stations 2.5) # of women and children assisted with legal aid services 2.6) # of lawyers contacted in the BA for pro bono representation, and # of cases represented
3.1) % of reports submitted on time to UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures 3.2) % of Universal Periodic Review (UPR) recommendations fully implemented by the Government of Tanzania

comment.narrative:
1.1) 50% of all prisoners are in custody awaiting trial (16,551) 1.2) TBD
2.1) No adequate normative framework on legal aid in place for protection of women and other vulnerable groups 2.2) No adequate normative framework on legal aid in place for protection of women and other vulnerable groups 2.3) Limited number of individuals have access to legal aid services / Limited public legal information campaign 2.4) Though data are not available, perceptions that around 95% of people in prison have not been legally represented 2.5) Women and other vulnerable groups do not benefit from legal aid, particularly in criminal proceedings 2.6) Inefficient pro-bono system
3.1) 30% of reports submitted on time to UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures 3.2) Limited coordination between AGC, CHRAGG and civil society organizations on UPR monitoring

1. Support provided to operationalize the NCJF Secretariat and at least one training conducted to the Secretariat to coordinate and monitor implementation of NCJF actions. 2. Guidelines and tools for effectiveness of NCJF, including SOP for meetings, information sharing protocols between justice institutions are developed and in use 3. At least one national conference on criminal justice is conducted 4. Support development of the National Prosecution Service Five-year Strategic Plan (2019 – 2023) 5. At least two vehicles procured as a logistical support to the DPP and CHRAGG In facilitating the monitoring and inspection of places of detention across the country. 6. legal aid code of conduct for service providers developed, launched and disseminated assistance 8. At least three interactions and coordination meetings on the implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies, including the CEDAW Committee, action plans for concerned government stakeholders at central and local level are organized 9. Support provided to finalize the NHRAP

-The project supported a two days training to 25 NCJF Secretariat members on the mandate and functions of the CJF at regional and District levels to ensure effective coordination and monitoring of implementation of NCJF actions. -In order to ensure effectiveness of the NCJF, TORs for their operationalization were developed which includes terms of Reference for meetings and information sharing protocols between justice institutions -Support has been extended for development of the National Prosecution Service Five-year Strategic Plan (2019 – 2023) and the first draft of the plan has been finalized. -The project has supported procurement of two vehicles for the DPP's office and CHRAGG to facilitate monitoring and inspection of places of detention across the country, all procurement processes has been completed and vehicles are expected early January 2020 - The project has successful supported the development of legal aid code of conduct which was launched in April 2019 during the National legal aid symposium, however, some improvements were recommended and are expected to be completed by April 2020. - Three interaction meetings at technical level on implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies were conducted in Zanzibar and mainland where an implementation and monitoring plan for recommendations was developed - Support has been extended to develop the NHRAP which is at final stages, validation at technical and ministry level has been completed and now waiting for approval from the parliamentary standing committee on constitutional affairs.

1. Integrated Data Management System for the Criminal Justice System Developed and operationalized
2. The functional capacity of Secretariat of the National Criminal Justice Forum enhanced
3. Inspection visits conducted to prisons in at least three regions of Tanzania mainland
4. Registration and Performance Monitoring System for Legal Aid Providers developed and operationalized
5. Legal aid services provided to at least 1000 indigent and vulnerable
6. Development of an Action Plan for the implementation of the UPR recommendations
7. Furniture for Planning and Coordination Unit procured and handed over to CHRAGG.
8. The National Human Rights Action Plan developed, printed and disseminated
9. CHRAGG Communication and Visibility Strategy developed, printed and disseminated.

1. In 2018, UNDP supported the Ministry in developing and operationalising an Integrated Data Management System for the criminal justice system in Tanzania. For a start, the Integrated Data Management System has targeted three institutions including the National Prosecution Service (previously DPP), the Tanzanian Police Force and the Tanzania Prison Service. The Integrated Data Management System has enabled data management and sharing across the criminal justice making for effective and timely resolution of cases and ultimately justice service delivery. The Integrated Data Management System is, at present, being reviewed to assess the possibility of integration it with the Government of Tanzania e-justice programme.
2. The functional capacity of the secretariat of the National Criminal Justice Forum has been reinforced through the provision of logistical support in the form of computers, printers and other equipment as well as technical support through the development of terms of reference and standard operating procedures for the Forum. This support to the Secretariat has been critical in reinforcing effectiveness and efficiency and in enabling the provision of effective coordination and secretariat support to the National Criminal Justice Forum.
3.Support has been provided to the National Prosecution Service in undertaking inspection visits to prisons in Kigoma, Geita, Kagera and Mwanza respectively. The team toured the prisons and places of detention in examining their current capacity, sanitary and hygiene situation. In all, the team examined a total of 75 cases and grant relief to 15 individuals through for instance the issuance of Nolle Prosequi and the grant of other relief.
4. Ministry of Constitutional and Legal Affairs (MoCLA) has been supported in developing a Web-based Registration and Performance Monitoring System for Legal Aid Providers. The overall purpose of the Web-based System is to support MoCLA in facilitating the registration and monitoring of LAPs and in monitoring their performances in the provision of legal aid services. The web-based platform shall be instrumental in avoiding undue costs and enabled MoCLA and legal aid providers to conduct the processes of registration without physically having to travel long distances. Furthermore, if fully operationalized, this web-based platform is now a critical tool in enabling MoCLA monitor the performance of legal aid providers as well as in tracking progress towards the full implementation of the Legal Aid Act in Tanzania.
5. Over the last 12 months, the project has achieved good progress in putting in place systems for the provision of services to indigent and vulnerable populations in Tanzania. Within this framework, support was provided to MoCLA for the planning and organisation of the Legal Aid Week which facilitated the delivery of free legal services to indigent and vulnerable people across the country. Preliminary figures compiled on the legal aid week indicate that nationally over 500,000 people were reached with legal services. Furthermore, a grant-making process has also been launched which has resulted in the selection of 6 national organisations with experience and track-record in legal aid service provision. While the provision of legal aid services by the selected organisations is yet to be operational, the appropriate groundwork is being finalised in clearing the way for service in 2019.
6. In furtherance this target, support has been provided to MoCLA for the development of an action plan on the implementation of the UPR reporting. In this regard, an orientation training and consultative meeting were organised in enhancing the capacity of the Ministry in understanding the UPR process and in identifying a core group of officials in facilitating the process. The development of the action plan is envisaged for 2019.
7. The Access to Justice project has reinforced the functional capacity of CHRAGG through the procurement of an assortment of furniture for its Planning and Coordination Unit. The furniture includes chairs of different assortments, office and conference tables, shelves, cabinets etc. This logistical support to CHRAGG has been critical to enhancing the capacity to provide effective planning and coordination support to Commission.
8. A draft of the National Human Rights Action Plan has been prepared by a national and an international consultant with the leadership of MoCLA and in collaboration with the Commission for Human Rights and Good Governance and other non-governmental actors. However, the draft is yet to be finalized and shall be put through a series of reviews which shall culminate into a validation process which is expected to roll over into 2019.
9. In 2018, CHRAGG was supported in developing a Five Years Communication and Visibility Strategy for the Commission. The documents were developed and finalised through a multi-stakeholders consultative and participatory process which culminated into a validation workshop where the documents were finalised and certified. A total of 100 copies of Communication and Visibility Strategy has been printed and disseminated.

-At least one national criminal justice conference and working groups meeting is Coordinated and conducted aiming at enhancing efficiency in investigation and prosecution and the overall functional and operational capacity of the National Criminal Justice Forum (NCJF). -Technical expertise and training to NCJF Working groups on selected priority group on selected priority areas i.e. non-custodial sentencing, legal aid, plea bargaining is provided -Support to meetings of zonal coordination committees to selected regions including quarterly zonal meetings is provided -Provide Technical and logistical support for establishment of legal clinic at the Law School Tanzania (LST). -Provide support on awareness raising and training to justice and law enforcement officers on legal aid for violations of rights, prevention and response to SGBV as well as other critical areas of need. -Provide support to facilitate the Ministry to participate in National events related to Legal Aid. -At least three interactions and coordination meetings on the implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies, including the CEDAW Committee, action plans for concerned government stakeholders at central and local level are organized -Provide support for quarterly coordination meetings and forums between CHRAGG and CSO on human rights issues and assessing the status of human rights in Tanzania. -Project Mid term evaluation conducted
